subject: RE: [junit] Test Order Execution
msgSnippet: True, *but* There s nothing (I can remember) in the JUnit docs that states what order the tests will be run. In differents versions they might run in different
messageBody:
True,

*but*

There's nothing (I can remember) in the JUnit docs that states what order
the tests will be run. In differents versions they might run in different
orders.

Also. Tests should be independent from one another.
If you need to test the Get then you will have to do a Set first. However
this test should be concentrating on the results of the Get rather than the
success of the Set.
If this means you are duplicating code then it's time to start refactoring.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
> Sent: 14 February 2002 13:34
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Test Order Execution
>
>
> Quoting "Heath, Joseph" <HeathJ@...>:
>
> > JUnit doesnt guarantee the order of the tests. Your tests
> shouldnt rely
> > on
> > other tests being executed before them.
>
> True, you shouldn't depend on the order of execution of
> tests, but if you must
> (and sometimes it's just easier that way), you *can* control
> the order in which
> tests are run.
>
> Understand that you don't have to name your test methods
> "testX". That was a
> convention that became a standard, leading to a convenience
> feature in xUnit.
> You can always build your test suite by hand:
>
> public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
> public static Test suite() {
> final TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("myTestMethod1"));
> suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("myTestMethod2"));
> suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("myTestMethod3"));
> suite.addTest(new MyTestCase("myTestMethod4"));
> }
> ...
> }
>
> DOWNSIDE: You must keep the suite up to date as you change
> the test methods in
> the test case. You will forget. It will cause you problems.
> If those problems
> are small compared to your current problem, then you should
> consider doing
> this; otherwise, you should take the time to learn about your
> design by
> exploring how to remove the dependency.
>
> > > I'm currently developing JUnitEE for use with a J2EE
> > > application, and admit to being relatively new to J2EE and
> > > JUnit. However, I am getting problems running test suites as
> > > the order of execution does not appear to be constant.
> <snip />
>
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> President, Diaspar Software Services
